title-group.article-title: Dempster–Shafer evidence theory approach to structural damage detection

contrib-group.aff: 1School of Civil Engineering, Harbin Institute of Technology, Harbin 150090, China.
2School of Civil and Hydraulic Engineering, Dalian University of Technology, Dalian 116024, China.

author-notes.corresp: Hui Li, School of Civil Engineering, Harbin Institute of Technology, Harbin 150090, China Email: lihui@hit.edu.cn

permissions.copyright-statement: © The Author(s) 2011 Reprints and permissions: sagepub.co.uk/journalsPermissions.nav

abstract.p: In this study, the Dempster–Shafer (D–S) evidence theory-based approach for structural damage detection is presented. First, the damage basic probability assignment (BPA) function of substructures using each data set measured from the monitored structure is calculated. Then, the D–S evidence theory is employed to combine the individual damage BPAs in order to reach the final damage detection results. To reduce the computational cost of this method when used in complex structures, the preliminary damage range is first localized by modal strain energy method. An experimental investigation on a 20-bay rigid truss structure is carried out to illustrate the identified ability of the proposed approach with considering the uncertainty of model and measurement noise. The results indicate that the damage detection results obtained by combining the damage BPAs from each test data are better than the individual results obtained by each test data separately.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Many damage identification methods based on vibration tests have been proposed in the past 30 years; these include the methods based on frequency variation, variation of mode shapes, flexibility matrix, statistic pattern damage detection, wavelet transformation, and others. However, the uncertainties caused by measurement noise, modeling error involved in an analytical model, and environmental changes such as variations in temperature and load conditions can impede reliable identification of damage.1 As a powerful tool for dealing with this uncertainty, the traditional probability theory has been used widely in structural damage detection. According to the difference of the statistical inference principle, the statistical methods in structural damage detection can be sorted into two classes: (1) the Bayesian probabilistic approach and (2) the stochastic finite element (FE) method.

Beck2 first used the Bayesian probabilistic method to identify the system parameters of structures. After a series research projects related to this subject, Beck and his co-workers3–9 constructed the Bayesian probabilistic framework for structural modal updating and damage identification. The Bayesian probabilistic framework for structural damage detection can be introduced as follows. First, the stiffness matrix of the structure’s FE model is parameterized, so that the elements of the structural model are grouped into substructures. The scaling factor of each substructure is defined as the model parameters. Then, the conditional probability density function (PDF) of the scaling factor is calculated by Bayesian’s theorem using the test modal parameters such as frequencies, mode shapes, and strain mode shapes. From this conditional PDF, a probabilistic damage measure is developed. In the Bayesian approach, finding the global optimal solutions for the model parameters is an important problem. Katafygiotis and Beck6 investigated the unidentifiable case of a model updating problem based on the Bayesian statistical framework and an asymptotic approximation method is presented for computing the optimal model parameters. Beck and Au8 proposed a method using the Markov chain Monte-Carlo simulation to solve the Bayesian problem of locally identifiable and unidentifiable cases. Ching et al.9 used Gibbs sampler, a stochastic simulation method, to calculate the model parameters for structural model updating and health monitoring using incomplete modal data.

The stochastic FE method for structural damage detection uses the perturbation theory to construct the relation between the model parameters and the test modal parameters of the structures. Then, the mean and variance of the model parameters can be computed by the test data or the simulated data using the Monte-Carlo method. Also, like the Bayesian approach, a probabilistic damage measure is developed and the damage probability of the structure can be obtained by this measure. Ricles and Kosmatka10 presented a damage detection method using vibratory residual forces and weighted sensitivity based on the stochastic FE method and perturbation theory. Papadopoulos and Carica11 used the Monte-Carlo method to compute the covariance matrix of the residual error of the model parameters, and the PDF of the model parameters is employed for damage detection of the structure. Hua et al.12 presented an improved perturbation method for the statistical identification of structural parameters using the measured modal parameters with randomness.

As an extension to Bayesian theory, the Dempster–Shafer (D–S) evidence theory is widely used as a method for combining multi-information following certain combination rules. Some researchers have investigated the application of the D–S evidence in fault diagnosis and structural damage detection. For fault diagnosis, the D–S evidence theory is employed to combine multi-information measured from multiple information sources for increasing accuracy of the fault diagnosis results.13–19 For structural damage detection, D–S evidence theory is used to investigate the structural damage detection methods.20,21 Guo and Zhang20 used the D–S evidence theory to identify multiple damage locations of a structure. Multiple evidences from different sources of different importance or reliability do not identically contribute to the damage detection when they are combined using D–S evidence theory. Consequently, a weighted balance evidence theory was proposed to solve this problem. Li et al.21 proposed a damage identification method based on the combination of artificial neural network, D–S evidence theory-based information fusion and the Shannon entropy, to form a weighted and selective information fusion technique to reduce the impact of uncertainties on damage identification.

In long-time monitoring of structural health, a number of data sets measured from multi-sensors are available. Therefore, the damage detection results can be updated using the continual accumulation of multi-sensor data to reduce the uncertainties caused by the measurement noise. The Bayesian probabilistic method has been successfully used to continuously monitor the damage of the structures using multiple data sets.7,22 As an alternative approach, in this article, the D–S evidence theory is employed to combine the damage detection results from the individual data sets. The effects of the D–S evidence theory for structural damage detection is illustrated by an experimental example.

sec.title: A brief introduction on D–S evidence theory
sec.p: D–S evidence theory is a mathematical theory of evidence, which uses the basic probability assignment (BPA) function, the belief (Bel) function, and the plausibility (Pl) function to quantify evidence and its uncertainty. One important aspect of this theory is that reasoning or decision making can be carried out with incomplete or conflicting pieces of evidence.15 For detailed tutorials on the subject, the reader can refer to Shafer,23 Klein,24 Yager,25 and references cited therein. A short introduction to the D–S evidence theory is presented in this section.

For a finite set of mutually exclusive and exhaustive propositions Ω, also known as a frame of discernment, a power set 2Ω is the set of all the subsets of Ω including itself and a null set φ, e.g., for example, if Ω = {a, b, c}, then 2Ω = {φ, a, b, c, a ∪ b, a ∪ c, b ∪ c, a ∪ c}. The BPA (represented by m) is a function m: 2Ω → [0,1], such that: (1a) (1b)
The Bel and Pl measures are: (2) (3)

The Bel represents the minimal confidence that one lies in A or any subset of A, whereas the Pl represents the maximal confidence that we believe A. These two measures are, in reality, the lower and upper bounds of the probability of A.

The BPA of evidence can be combined according to Dempster’s rule. Consider that the subset A has two information sources S1 and S2, and let m1 and m2 be the BPAs of sources S1 and S2, respectively. The BPA of A can be obtained using the following combination rule (4) (5) where k is the BPA that the combination assigns to the null subset. It reflects the conflict between two information sources S1 and S2.

sec.title: Basic principle of the damage detection approach
sec.p: A system stiffness matrix K can be expressed as an assembly of substructure stiffness matrices. For a model with Nα substructures, the system stiffness matrix is represented as follows: (6) where Ki is the stiffness matrix of the αi (0 ≤i ≤ 1) a nondimensional parameter which represents the contribution of the ith substructure stiffness to the overall system stiffness matrix.

Modal data sets are assumed to be collected and estimated from repeated or continuous vibration tests. The modal data for the nth test is referred to by Λ^n. (7) where ω^r(n),φ^r(n), and Ψ^r(n) denote the rth estimated frequency, mode shape, and strain mode shape in the nth data set, respectively. Nm the number of measured modes. The superscript T denotes matrix or vector transpose. When vibration tests are repeated Ns times, the total collection of Ns modal data set is denoted by D^t={ Λ^1,Λ^2,…,Λ^Ns }.
Let Hi,d and Hi,ud denote the damaged and undamaged states of the ith substructure, respectively. According to the D–S evidence theory, the frame of discernment is defined as follows: (8)

It is composed of two exhaustive and exclusive hypotheses. From the frame of discernment Θi, let us denote 2Θi, the power set composed with the 22 propositions of Θi (9) where Θi denotes that the decision maybe Hi,d or Hi,ud, so the Θi implies the uncertainty of a decision.

A structural health monitoring system can provide a number of measurement data with progressive monitoring time. It is assumed that Nt groups of D^t(t=1,2,…,Nt) are extracted from the monitoring data at different times. Then, the BPAs are: (10) where m0(i) is the prior BPA and m0(i)(t=1,2,…,Nt) the posterior BPA of the elements of power set 2Θi for the tth group on D^t. The superscript (i) denotes the ith substructure. The BPAs m0(i) and m1(i) can be combined using the D–S combination rule of Equations (4) and (5). First, the combination of the BPAs of m0(i) and mt(i) is given in Table 1. To calculate the combined BPA for a subset of the power set 2Θi, simply multiply the BPAs from the associated column and row. Table 1.

m01(i)(ϕi) m(φi) = 0 m(φi) = 0 m(φi) = 0 m(φi) = 0
m0(i)(Hi,d) m(φi) = 0 m(Hi,d)=m0(i)(Hi,d)m1(i)(Hi,d) m(ϕi)=m0(i)(Hi,d)m1(i)(Hi,ud) m(Hi,d)=m0(i)(Hi,d)m1(i)(Θi)
m0(i)(Hi,ud) m(φi) = 0 m(ϕi)=m0(i)(Hi,ud)m1(i)(Hi,d) m(Hi,ud)=m0(i)(Hi,ud)m1(i)(Hi,ud) m(Hi,ud)=m0(i)(Hi,ud)m1(i)(Θi)

Then, using Equations (1), (4), and (5), the BPAs can be expressed as (11a) (11b) (11c) (11d) (11e) where the m01(i) means the combined BPA of two BPAs m0(i) and m1(i).
Then, using the same combination procedures of m0(i) and m1(i), the combination of m01(i) and m2(i) can be represented as (12a) (12b) (12c) (12d) (12e)
Finally, by analogy, the m012⋯t(i)(ϕi)=0 can be derived as (13a) (13b) (13c) (13d) (13e) where t = 1,2, …, Nt and i = 1,2,…Nα.

sec.title: Calculation of BPAs
sec.p: According to the Bayesian probabilistic damage detection methodology proposed by Vanik et al.,7 the uncertainties in the values of the parameters α=[ α1, α2,…, αNα ]T are quantified by PDFs that are obtained using the dynamic test data sets D^t. (14) where (15) where S is a diagonal matrix of variances of α, which reflects the level of uncertainty in the nominal model; α0 is generally chosen as α0 = [1, 1, …,1]T to reflect that the nominal structural model as the most probable model in the absence of any data; Jr(α) is (16) where (17a) (17b) (17c)

The matrices Γφ and Γψ are the observation matrices that pick the observed degrees of freedom from the mode shapes ϕr and ψr (make the dimension of ϕr and ψr be identical to that of φ^r and ψ^r) and ϕr and ψr are the calculated mode shapes using the structural model with the parameter α. The deduction details of Equations (14)–(17) can be found in Vanik et al.,7 the only difference here is that the strain mode shapes are also used, such as the third item in the right-hand side of Equation (16).

The marginal PDFs for the αi can be obtained by integrating the joint PDF in Equation (14) using Laplace’s method for asymptotic expansion: (18) where ϕ is the standard Gaussian PDF; α^i is the most probable model obtained by minimizing J(α) in Equation (15); α^i2 is the ith diagonal element of L(α^)−1, where L(α^)−1 is the Hessian matrix of J(α) evaluated at α^.

The damage probability of the ith substructure P(i) is defined as (19) where di ∈[ 0,1 ] is the damage threshold for the ith substructure; the superscripts ud and pd denote the undamaged structure and the possibly damaged structure, respectively; and D^ud and D^pd are the data sets obtained from undamaged structure and possibly damage structure, respectively.
The approximate calculation of probabilistic damage measure of substructure is given by Vanik et al.7 as follows: (20)

The tth BPAs mt(i)(ϕi), mt(i)(Hi,d), mt(i)(Hi,ud), and mt(i)(Θi) are defined as follows: (21a) (21b) (21c) (21d) where t = 1, 2,…,Nt·η ∈[0,1] is the weighting coefficient which reflects the reliability of damage decision of substructures using the Bayesian method. The same η is employed for Equation 21(b)–(d). If there are no any data available at the initial stage, the prior BPAs are defined as follows: (22a) (22b) (22c) (22d) where m0(i)(Θi)=1 implies that the damage state of the structure has the maximum uncertainty.

sec.title: Preliminary damage localization
sec.p: For the complex structure, it is difficult to exactly localize damage by one step. In fact, the calculation of BPAs of the substructures using Bayesian method is an optimal problem, which dramatically increases the calculation cost. To reduce the calculation cost, the potential damage range is priorly detected by the modal strain energy method due to sensitive to the local variation in mode shape, which is a damage index proposed by Stubbs et al.26 based on the changes in the curvature of the rth mode at location j: (23) where φ^r″(j) and φ^rd″(j) are the jth (j = 1, 2, …, Nj) elements of the second derivatives of the measured rth displacement mode shape corresponding to the undamaged and damaged structures, respectively; Nj the number of measured locations. If more than one mode is used, the damage index is the mean of the damage indices from each mode: (24)

Once the preliminary damage locations are detected, the nondimensional parameters α of those substructures only around the preliminary damage locations are selected as the parameters to be further identified by D–S evidence theory-based information fusion technique. Consequently, the dimension of parameters α of an entire structure to be identified is condensed to a small dimension and the calculation cost is reduced.

sec.title: Procedure of the proposed damage detection approach
sec.p:
The flow chart of the damage identification procedure is shown in Figure 1. The first step in the flow chart is to find the potential damage localizations using the damage index of Equations (23) and (24). Then, the initial BPAs are first obtained from the data sets at the monitoring early stage using the method presented in ‘Calculation of BPAs’ section. The BPAs are updated using the measured multi-data sets in progressive time sequence by D–S combination rule for obtaining the exact damaged substructures. In the progressive updating procedures, the impact of uncertainties on damage detection decision made from each single data set will be reduced and the accuracy of final damage detection decision can be improved. Figure 1.
Flow chart of the damage detection approach.

sec.title: Experimental study
sec.p:
The 20-bay rigid truss structure for experiment is shown in Figure 2, of which the total length, width, and height are 8.0, 0.8, and 0.56 m, respectively. It consists of 312 members with 108 nodes and all the members are steel bars of which the Young’s modulus and density are 2.06×105 MPa and 7800 kg/m3, respectively. The connections of the members are bolt-node balls which are the half-rigidity connections. There are two supports at the ends of the structure: a hinge support at the right end and a vertical roller support at the left. Figure 2.
Experimental model: 20-bay rigid truss structure.

The accelerometers are installed at all nodes of the bottom chord, as shown in Figure 3(a), and the locations of the accelerometers are shown in Figure 4(a). Due to the limitation of amount of accelerometers, each test of damage case is carried out twice, i.e., each test measures the half span of the structure, and the S10 and S29 are chosen as the reference measurement locations. The strain gages and optical fiber Bragg grating (FBG) strain sensors are pasted on the bars of two side chords, as shown in Figure 3(b) and (c), and the locations of all strain gages and FBG sensors are shown in Figure 5. The data acquisition systems for collecting the time history response of acceleration and strain are shown in Figure 6. The sampling frequency for accelerometer, strain gage, and FBG sensor are 200, 500, and 500 Hz, respectively. Figure 3.
Sensors on the members of the structure: (a) accelerometer; (b) strain gage; and (c) FBG strain sensor. Figure 4.
Locations of the accelerometers: (a) bottom chord and (b) top chord. Figure 5.
Locations of the strain gages and FBG strain sensors: (a) one side of the truss and (b) other side of the truss. Figure 6.
Data acquisition systems: (a) acceleration data acquisition system and (b) strain gage and FBG sensor data acquisition systems.

The damage is simulated by screwing the bolt and separating member from bolted sphere node, such as the damage case 1 in Figure 7 and damage case 2 in Figure 8, where damage case 1 is that the connection of member 9 with sphere node is taken off and damage case 2 is that both the connections of members 10 and 25 with sphere node are broken off. The members marked with 1–34 are shown in Figures 4 and 5, which are nearby the damage members and their status (such as strain, deformation, etc.) may be influenced by the damaged elements. The locations of two damage cases in the truss are shown in Figure 9, which show the damage bars location. Figure 7.
Damage case 1. Figure 8.
Damage case 2. Figure 9.
Damage locations of cases 1 and 2.

The modal parameters such as the frequencies, mode shapes, and strain modes are identified by eigen-system realization algorithm (ERA) combined with natural excitation technique (NExT). NExT and ERA are representative modal identification methods that have been widely used in the field of modal analysis. The test frequencies are given in Table 2, which show that the variation of frequencies is little. Two vertical displacement mode shapes and one strain mode are shown in Figures 10–13, where the simulation results are obtained by the FE model of the undamaged truss. Figure 10.
Analytical and experimental mode shapes of the undamaged structure: (a) first vertical displacement mode shape and (b) first vertical torsion mode shape. Figure 11.
Experimental mode shapes of damage case 1: (a) first vertical displacement mode shape and (b) first vertical torsion mode shape. Figure 12.
Experimental mode shapes of damage case 2: (a) first vertical displacement mode shape and (b) first vertical torsion mode shape. Figure 13.
First strain modes of the damaged and undamaged structures: (a) first strain mode of undamaged structure; (b) first strain mode of structure with damage case 1; and (c) first strain mode of structure with damage case 2. Table 2.
Frequencies of the undamaged and damaged structures
Order Undamaged Damaged
Calculation by FE model (Hz) Test (Hz) Variation (%) Case 1 (Hz) Variation (%) Case 2 (Hz) Variation (%)
1 18.871 18.1489 3.83 17.4920 3.62 17.8959 1.39
2 53.841 52.9509 1.65 52.5724 0.71 51.8226 2.13

Preliminary damage localization results using modal strain energy index are shown in Figures 14 and 15, which indicates that the damage locations are near the measurement point 6 for damage case 1 and measurement points 6 and 25 for damage case 2, respectively. The elements near the test points 6 and 25 are selected as the possible damage elements. Therefore, the elements 1–18 and 1–34 are chosen as possible damage elements for damage cases 1 and 2, respectively, as shown in Figures 4 and 5. The parameters α of only these elements are to be identified and updated by the proposed D–S evidence theory-based information fusion approach. Figure 14.
Preliminary damage localization of damage case 1. Figure 15.
Preliminary damage localization of damage case 2.

For obtaining more experimental data, the test for each damage cases is repeated for 10 times, i.e., Nt = 10. In each test, the measured data are divided into 20 sets for obtaining the Ns groups of modal parameters D^t={ Λ^1,Λ^2,⋯,Λ^Ns }, where t = 1, 2, …, Nt. Then, the BPAs (m0(i), m1(i), m2(i),…,mNt(i), i = 1, 2,…,Nα) for each test can be obtained using the method presented in ‘Calculation of BPAs’ section. The weighted coefficient is estimated as η = 0.85. The BPAs from the multiple data sets can be combined using Equations (11)–(13). The element with large BPA is regarded as the damaged member.

Damage detection results of damage case 1 are shown in Figure 16. The damage threshold di is set at reduction in stiffness by 10% for all substructures. Figure 16(a) shows the damage detection results obtained using each individual data set separately, where the damage elements almost can be detected by each test t, but the damage locations are not shown clearly. However, the results shown in Figure 16(b) are better, which shows the continuous update of BPAs using D–S evidence theory. The BPA of ‘Update 1’ in Figure 16(b) is the same with ‘Test 1,’ and the BPA of ‘Update 2’ is the BPA combined by the BPAs of ‘Test 1’ and ‘Test 2’ using D–S combination rule. The same process is implemented from ‘Update 3’ to ‘Update 10’ for updating the damage BPAs. Figure 16(b) shows that better diagnosis can be obtained by continually updating the damage BPAs using multiple data sets than just using each test data separately. After updating 10 times, the uncertainty of damage detection results is decreased and the damage element is identified clearly. Same conclusion can also be drawn out from Figure 17, which shows the results of damage case 2, although the damage elements are not detected correctly. Element 26 is a misidentification, which is directly related with the damage element 25. Figure 16.
Damage detection results of damage case 1: (a) damage BPAs computed from individual data set of damage case 1 and (b) damage BPAs after continuous updating using D–S evidence theory of damage case 1. Figure 17.
Damage detection results of damage case 2: (a) damage BPAs computed from individual data set of damage case 2 and (b) damage BPAs after continuous updating using D–S evidence theory of damage case 2.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: In this study, a structural damage detection method based on D–S evidence theory is proposed, which uses D–S evidence theory to combine the damage detection results from different individual data sets for reducing the uncertainty caused by the measurement noise and model error. For the complex structures, the proposed approach can decrease the computational cost through localizing the damage zone prior to conduct damage detection using the D–S evidence theory. In the experimental examples, modal parameters including frequencies, mode shapes, and strain modes extracted from multi-sensor data are used for damage identification. The experimental results indicate that better diagnosis can be obtained by continually updating the damage BPAs using the D–S evidence theory based on multiple data sets, rather than just using each test data separately.
